The M5 entered production in April 1942 as a development of the M3 platform adapted to utilize power from Cadillac V8 engines in lieu of the M3’s radial engine, which was vulnerable to short supply due to demand for aircraft applications. The updated M5A1 variant arrived in late 1942 with an extended turret allowing space for a more powerful radio. The dual-pin steel tracks feature rubber tread blocks and roll under four spoked road wheels on each side, while also utilizing idler wheels at the rear of the tank and three return rollers each. The Stuart M5A1 uses vertical volute suspension. The turret hosts height-adjustable seats for a tank commander/loader and a gunner. Equipment includes a Signal Corps radio, ammunition boxes, and provisions for three periscopes. The hull houses adjustable seating for a driver and co-driver, each provided with ceiling-mounted steering tillers and an accelerator pedal. The odometer is not legible, and mileage is unknown. The dual 346ci Cadillac V8 gasoline engines feature side valves, downdraft carburetors, and horizontally mounted radiators.
